newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Bardot cleared of racist slur.
newsitem.headline: France's Bardot cleared of racist slur.

text.p: A Paris court on Thursday cleared former film star Brigitte Bardot of inciting racial hatred in saying that France was being invaded by sheep-slaughtering Moslems.
The court said her comments were "above all the expression of rebellion against animal distress made as part of a passionate struggle for animal rights".
Cheered by fans and animal lovers, the 62-year-old former screen sex symbol who has come under fire for far-right views, had denied the charges at a December 19 hearing.
The Movement Against Racism (MRAP) said it would appeal against the ruling which it criticised as "incomprehensible" and tantamount to granting impunity to authors of racist comments.

MRAP, the Human Rights League and the League Against Racism and Anti-Semitism had filed the complaints agains Bardot which if upheld, could have led to up to a year in prison and a 300,000-franc ($60,000) fine under French laws against inciting racial hatred.
The ex-actress turned animal rights activist was sued for her outspoken criticism of the Moslem ritual slaughter of sheep and of immigration into France from Moslem countries.
The court found her criticism of Moslem "overpopulation" was excessive but could not be banned in a democratic society.
"Ruling otherwise would go against our democratic principles by making some issues taboo and virtually allowing prosecution of opinions, which is not what the legislator wanted," it said.
In an opinion column in the conservative daily Le Figaro last April, Bardot said the traditional throat-slitting of sheep for the Aid-al-Kebir Moslem feast was barbarous and went against French law.
"France, my country, my homeland, my land is again being invaded with the blessing of successive governments by a foreign overpopulation, mainly Moslem, to which we pay allegiance," she wrote.
"Mosques flourish while our churchbells go silent for lack of priests," she wrote.
Public prosecutor Marie-Jeanne Vieillard had accused Bardot of denouncing Moslem traditions but had not requested a specific punishment.
